California (at Least Thus Far) Commission voted order 5-0, essentially appeared yesterday. Three key changes: clarified surcharge applies Access customers (but entire "rate freeze" structure remains now). Commission reversed chose adopt TURN's "netting out" gen revenues CTC collections, said Commission consider option next phase (a move likely made order lower chances successful utility appeal). Commission added decision language saying study pros/cons securitizating utilities' power purchase costs. submit report issue Governor Legislature. last point, wire reports rampant possibility legislation early today proposing securitize utilties' power purchase costs. action reportedly result discussions occured night governor's office, utilities ratings agencies reponse fact decision issued PUC falls well short what's needed keep IOUs credit worthy solvent. result wires stories, utilities' stock come back (Edison low 6.25 currently 10 7/8; PG&E 8 7/8 currently 11 7/8). We're working Sandi McCubbin, legislative activities California, info report back. hearing highly charged anti-generator, anti-marketer rhetoric, likely play prominent role press accounts. FERC demonized more. Commissioners, including recent "interim" appointee, strong statements regarding undesirability utility bankruptcy. "I think everything table," Senate President Pro Tem John Burton told reporters. avoid huge spikes electricity prices likely hottest issue facing Legislature prepares 2001 session. Electricity bills tripled rate deregulation plan approved Legislature 1996 kicked year customers San Diego Gas Electric Co. California's two huge investor-owned utilities, Southern California Edison Pacific Gas & Electric Co., say suffered $5 billion $6 billion losses increases wholesale electricity prices they've waited deregulation fully affect them. may ask Legislature permission raise rates make losses can't get authorization Public Utilities Commission courts. Burton questioned whether utilities lost much. "I know they've got problems, like baseball teams saying lose money," San Francisco Democrat said. "Well, lose money cause depreciate Alex Rodriguez's $20 million contact. ain't losing money making money." PG&E spokesman Ron Low said Burton raised "legitimate questions" said company's losses real. "The fact cannot continue keep borrowing money pay high wholesale prices," Low said. "We filed reports commission month detail seriousness situation." Burton said PUC needs audit utility company books. "If running broke who's responsibility bail out: state, ratepayers, share holders?" Burton asked. "Those easy questions answer." said consumer advocates believe utility stock holders eat losses utilities believe customers pay cover them. "Maybe something between," Burton said. Asked taxpayers chip in, said one possible way try hold prices would develop power generation systems would fully partially owned public. "Public power around years," said. "It worked years." Jan Smutny-Jones, executive director Independent Energy Producers, association privately owned power plant companies, said there's need build publicly owned facilities. "Energy coming California...," said, adding five power plants construction state now. "Getting market back track require massive amounts legislation." Another option re-regulate utility rates, Burton said. "I never found burden think burden ratepayers," said. lawmakers fail solve problem, consumer advocates put public power system initiative ballot pass overwhelmingly, Burton predicted. Spokesmen power generators utilities immediately respond request Associated Press comment. Copyright , Sacramento Bee *********** Gentlemen: favorable responses regarding use Volatility Reduction Method (Roger, I've attached copy article case seen it). However, continued quibble create set data points would inputs testing process. Last week consulting arm "Big Five" accounting firm indicated following method proposed us would acceptable. believe method overcomes statistical problems arise using interest rate differences overlapping ("rolling") quarters. Method: 1)Calculate daily yield curve changes expressed ratios, using historical rates recent, say, two years. (Note: overlap). results set around 494 vectors ratios (approximately 247 trading days per year). Example: first three yield curves historical set look like this: 19980801 6.5 6.6 6.7 ......... 7.2 19980802 6.3 6.3 6.6 ......... 6.9 19980803 6.6 6.8 6.9 ......... 7.1 change 8/1/98 8/2/98 is: 6.3/6.5 6.3/6.6 6.6/6.7 .......... 6.9/7.1 change 8/2/98 8/3/98 is: 6.6/6.3 6.8/6.3 6.9/6.6 ......... 7.1/6.9 2)Randomly select 62 "ratio" vectors (approx. 62 trading days quarter). 3)Multiply ratio vectors together get single vector (ie, 62 6mo ratios multiplied together, 62 1yr ratios multiplied togeter, etc.). result represents single quarterly yield curve transformation. Apply "today's" yield curve. resulting yield curve represents one simulated quarterly change interest rates 4)Repeat steps 2 3 adequate number yield curves generated, say 100. 5) Proceed testing process. would interested comments. BYLINE: NANCY VOGEL, TIMES WRITER DATELINE: SACRAMENTO BODY: ˜˜California's immediate electricity crisis seems passed. hurricane tropical island, crisis radically altered 27 million Californians get electricity pay it. ˜˜Not state's energy problems disappeared; siege hot weather, example, could still bring shortages. change short-term energy picture since blackout days early spring hard overstate. ˜˜A megawatt-hour cost hundreds, sometimes thousands, dollars regularly sells less $80. ˜˜There forced outage since May 8. ˜˜Predictions California would suffer 260 hours blackouts summer seem ludicrous. ˜˜The state government, spending average $65 million day buy power May, pays average less $30 million day. Basking unexpectedly cool summer weather, government much power hand days sell surplus electricity loss. ˜˜That sudden shift, crisis calm, obscures equally dramatic change California's long-term approach electricity gets bought sold. ˜˜Just three years ago, state embarked broad deregulation scheme designed put decisions electricity private marketplace. ˜˜Now, state government become biggest buyer power West. ˜˜The state's two largest utilities, already stripped deregulation much ability generate electricity, are, least temporarily, also power-buying business. Financially wounded, maybe crippled, role sharply curtailed, perhaps years. ˜˜Utility rates paid millions customers raised, state's utility watchdog, used control rates, poised yield much authority unlikely agency: Department Water Resources, whose principal job January running reservoirs canals. ˜˜And consumers seem almost certain saddled billions dollars debt contracts buy power practically guarantee high electricity rates years come. ˜˜The two sets changes, short-term long, interconnected. stem state's dramatic entry market seven months ago. ˜˜On Jan. 17, blackouts darkened much state. Power plant owners refused sell electricity Pacific Gas & Electric Southern California Edison, state's two biggest utilities, nearly drained cash eight months soaring wholesale power prices prevented state raising rates consumers. ˜˜Four private energy companies warning would take two utilities Bankruptcy Court next day state begin pick bill electricity. ˜˜Faced options rationing power, shocking California's economy tripling electricity rates opening state's checkbook, grim-faced Gov. Gray Davis signed emergency decree allow Department Water Resources use budget buy electricity would sold consumers. ˜˜That act, later broadened formalized Legislature, opened door taxpayer money--$8 billion counting--to used buy electricity. ˜˜"It's obligation provide power homes businesses drive California," Davis said time. "I'm disappointed utilities can't it. choice step in, it." ˜˜The involvement state buying power changed political calculations involved setting electricity rates. months, private utilities complained California's rates, frozen part state's deregulation law, lower cost buying power. raising rates help utilities politically unpalatable; Public Utilities Commission January gave fraction sought raising rates PG&E Edison residential customers 9%. ˜˜After state began buying power, though, California's treasury risk. Pressure built quickly rate hikes. March, PUC approved largest increase history, boosting rates customers 40%. ˜˜Those increases showed bills last month. higher costs conservation efforts reduced demand. Cooler-than-expected weather lowered demand even more. Californians used 12% less electricity last month June 2000, adjusting weather economic growth, according California Energy Commission. ˜˜Seven months state began buying power, January's sense urgency dissipated. Buyer's remorse setting in. Grumbling grows louder deeply state inserted electricity business. ˜˜It "huge mistake" let Department Water Resources become buyer electricity used California, said Bill Booth, attorney California Large Energy Consumers Assn., group heavy industry manufacturers pushed hard deregulation early 1990s. ˜˜"I would hope state entity chooses get role sooner rather later," Booth said. "The state shown zero capability well," said, voicing criticism also made Republican lawmakers. ˜˜Davis advisors argue little choice jump buy power behalf utilities. insist intervention stabilized market. ˜˜Long-Term Contracts Called 'Insurance' ˜˜After state government began buying electricity, officials moved quickly get state exorbitant spot market locking $43-billion worth long-term power contracts, lasting decade. Lawmakers consumer advocates growing increasingly critical contracts, expensive falling prices spot market. ˜˜But Davis administration officials insist spot market prices falling state buying 40% power contract, rather bidding prices seeking electricity market. ˜˜"Insurance insurance, costs little bit, damned good thing have," said S. David Freeman, governor's top energy advisor former general manager Los Angeles Department Water Power. ˜˜"The people ballgame criticize long-term contracts criticize anything stability God forbid may turn cost tiny bit spot market future," Freeman added. "That kind thinking leads spot market." ˜˜The shift spot market factor stabilized situation, however, accuse governor taking undue credit. ˜˜The change "clearly explained fundamentals supply, increased, demand, decreased people conserving," said Gary Ackerman, executive director Western Power Trading Forum, group electricity sellers. ˜˜The price natural gas, fuel used run California's power plants, fallen half since early January. widespread disagreement why--mirroring argument gas prices spiked first place. ˜˜When prices rose, electricity companies accused gas pipeline companies gouging. gas firms said power generators bid price knowing could recoup cost selling expensive megawatts. ˜˜Another factor lowering wholesale electricity prices state's overall power supplies abundant many power plants shut spring running again. ˜˜At times last winter, 10,000 megawatts capacity offline. Recent plant shutdowns totaled closer 4,000 megawatts. Three new power plants opened summer, adding 1,415 megawatts state's capacity. ˜˜Statewide demand electricity peaking little 30,000 megawatts recent days. ˜˜Again, reasons additional supply disputed. Generating companies say plants shut earlier year repairs maintenance. ˜˜State officials consumer advocates alleged plants taken offline manipulate prices. Today, less power bought spot market, fewer incentives manipulation. ˜˜A federal wholesale electricity price cap took effect June also also dampened prices, experts say. ˜˜The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission imposed cap, $92 per megawatt-hour, resisting pleas California politicians nearly year. ˜˜"They complete 180," said Severin Borenstein, director University California Energy Institute Berkeley, "and done earlier, would saved lot money." ˜˜The agency manages state's transmission grid found bids power sellers dropped June 21, price limit took effect. assessing much change resulted cap much factors "is difficult," said Anjali Sheffrin, director market analysis California Independent System Operator. ˜˜The changes market--and debate administration critics--involve pays risk. ˜˜Little Incentive Firms Trim Costs ˜˜Before deregulation 1998, California's electricity industry designed avoid risk shortages. Utilities built cushion supply, regulators guaranteed could pass cost customers. ˜˜Critics said regulation left utilities little incentive trim costs, meaning ratepayers paid higher bills. ˜˜Deregulation supposed shift risk owning power generation private companies bought stock. Proponents said consumers would benefit private firms risked money build power plants competed one another sell electricity. ˜˜But practice, competition California brought price spikes supply shortages. ˜˜"The reason economists preached competition better regulation," said Ken Rose, executive director National Regulatory Research Institute Ohio State University Columbus, "is investor putting dollars line careful dollars. downside there's ability suppliers control prices, they'll exploit advantage, expect do. ˜˜"You can't make risk go away," said. ˜˜Now Californians face different risk: new, largely untested 96-person, $2-million-per-month bureaucracy designed buy power could run amok. ˜˜There's easy way disband power-buying operation utilities get back feet financially. could take years. April, PG&E filed bankruptcy fend creditors. Edison's finances started improve somewhat, company still seeking help Legislature, rescue plan seems gaining momentum. ˜˜In meantime, Department Water Resources little oversight goes newly assigned job buying electricity. ˜˜The Public Utilities Commission 80 years dictated rates utilities could charge. new rules proposed earlier month, PUC essentially become rubber stamp, adjusting rates customers PG&E, Edison San Diego Gas & Electric Co. match whatever amount money Department Water Resources says needed. ˜˜Even PUC officials say drastic loss control necessary allow state sell $13.4 billion bonds. bonds designed repay state's taxpayers past power costs. backed money customers pay PG&E, Edison SDG&E month. ˜˜That one ways drastic actions taken prevent energy meltdown hemmed policymakers trying envision future shape state's electricity industry. ˜˜"There certainly lot less room designing future many people would like," said state Sen. Debra Bowen (D-Marina del Rey). ˜˜For example, competition--the dream deregulators--appears dead least several years. ˜˜That's need pay long-term contracts reimburse state's general fund billions already spent. ˜˜The owners steel mills, cement plants grocery stores blanch cost contracts. chafing break utilities cut deals electricity private companies Enron Corp. one-on-one deals banned Legislature put state power-buying business. ˜˜"Ultimately, think companies buying power best solution," said Jack Stewart, president California Manufacturers Technology Assn. ˜˜But move would shift risks inherent electricity business. big firms walk away utilities would someone else--renters, homeowners small business owners--would bear cost maintaining cushion extra supply state. Many lawmakers reluctant allow that. ˜˜"Any kind meaningful competition California 2004, 2005, time long-term contracts start ending," said Michael Shames, executive director Utility Consumers' Action Network San Diego. ˜˜Ultimately, Davis said interview, "the long-term solution problem depends power need." ˜˜Generators base prices "on much power know have," Davis said. protect consumers gouged, said, state's goal always least 15% power needs. ˜˜Private companies never take risk building last power plants necessary ensure surplus, said Davis, state must. ˜˜To end, Davis backed law takes effect next month creating Public Power Authority. agency able sell $5 billion revenue bonds build, buy power plants finance energy efficiency conservation programs. ˜˜Ironically, governor said, new agency, "builder last resort," could clear way competition state's deregulation plan miserably failed achieve. ˜˜"We've never really chance test ideal world, we've never power need," governor said. BYLINE: Emily Bazar Bee Capitol Bureau BODY: ˜˜Despite high-profile role Gov. Gray Davis' top adviser, Lynn Schenk keeps decidedly low profile. ˜˜She shuns public attention refuses speak reporters. Schenk often seen whispering counsel governor's ear. ˜˜The attorney congresswoman become powerful force Democratic governor's administration, trust leader trusts precious few. ˜˜On every major policy decision, whether involves health care law enforcement, Davis elicits chief staff's opinion. high-stakes phone calls need made, entrusts task. last-minute negotiations, Davis sends Schenk represent table. ˜˜"There limits expects asks do," said Garry South, Davis' chief political adviser. Jerry Brown's administration. Davis Brown's chief staff, position awarded Schenk, Schenk first deputy secretary, secretary Business, Transportation Housing Agency. ˜˜Though two took divergent paths - entered business world served one term Congress began incremental ascent governorship - remained friends political allies. elected governor 1998, Davis asked Schenk assume toughest job administration. appointment $131,400-a-year post, Schenk, 56, became woman state's gubernatorial administrations. ˜˜Their similarities led numerous colleagues friends call Schenk Davis' "alter ego," designation would probably agree. ˜˜"I think there's anyone administration whose philosophical perspective closer mine hers," Davis said Schenk recently. ˜˜As one people Davis trusts, Schenk moved beyond duties traditional chief staff. ˜˜Howard Dickstein, prominent attorney, described Schenk focused tireless 1999 talks negotiate compacts regulate gambling Indian lands. sometimes scheduled meetings midnight. ˜˜Schenk also heavily involved talks last year bill state Sen. TAKE NOTE: CALIFORNIANS ALMOST UTILITIES OWING MONEY BYLINE: Karen Brandon. Karen Brandon Tribune staff reporter. BODY: ˜˜Nicole Eric Jorgensen missionaries land ripe potential converts. ˜˜Just energy apocalypse seems hand, husband-and-wife fervently preaching gospel conservation, growing number penitent energy consumers making pilgrimage Jorgensens' unassuming tract house San Jose, Calif. ˜˜The 1,150-square-foot home is, fact, kind miracle state still reeling fallout deregulation power-grid breakdown: utility bills nearly dwarf mortgage payments blackouts hit willy-nilly Third World country birthplace Information Age. ˜˜The couple's last utility bill $11.95, including gas, standard meter fees. electricity mostly solar- wind-generated, electric meter actually spins backward. virtually immune blackouts. power outage hit neighborhood one day Nicole heating lunch microwave, clue blank face digital clock electric stove, lone device run homemade power. ˜˜The Jorgensens' conservation ethos stems mixture outrage products feel use much electricity do, penny-pinching habits developed trying accumulate payment one nation's highest-priced real estate markets, certain spirit gamesmanship keeps asking, "How low go?" ˜˜Now trying wean fellow Californians profligate energy consumption one bulb, one outlet one appliance time. services much demand Eric quit day job Stanford University physicist work full time energy consultant. ˜˜The heart conservation need synonym sacrifice, even, Vice President Dick Cheney famously remarked, "a sign personal virtue." ˜˜"What advocate conserve way even know conserving," says Eric. ˜˜That would difficult Americans, come view appliances necessities could begin unplugging daily lives without feeling sacrifice. couple's methods mind-set-and less radical measures adopted Californians living ground zero energy crisis year-can instructive Chicagoans also face steadily rising energy costs experienced enough substation fires sudden outages doubt reliability Commonwealth Edison's power grid. ˜˜Long accustomed enduring one kind crisis (drought, earthquakes, riots) another (brush fires, mudslides, O.J. Simpson trial), Californians slow realize energy woes another seasonal nuisance. official pleas conservation, persistently high electric bills prospect prolonged power outages apparently beginning sink in. ˜˜A recent Los Angeles Times poll found energy considered No. 1 problem state, dwarfing traditional concerns education crime. though vast majority Californians believe electricity shortage artificially created power companies' manipulating market boost profits, residents told pollsters altering daily routines- switching lights often, using less air conditioning-to save electricity. ˜˜The shift attitude beginning show variety ways, electricity use 12 percent-14 percent peak times -from last June June, according California Energy Commission. ˜˜One barometer changing mood bottom line Real Goods, California company includes energy-conserving gadgets home solar systems inventory. Business quadrupled year ago company backlog 500 e-mail requests solar equipment, said John Schaeffer, company's founder chief executive officer. ˜˜In San Diego County, Shea Homes become first major home builder nation build suburb solar power standard feature new houses. recently opened subdivision 300 homes, priced mid-$500,000s, features solar water heating rooftop electricity panels generate 1,500 kilowatt hours year, quarter average home uses. ˜˜Up coast, new Santa Rita County Jail third buildings covered nearly 5,000 solar panels, said largest rooftop array Western Hemisphere. tony Carmel, former Mayor Clint Eastwood solar power golf country club. ˜˜Elsewhere, businesses installing battery-operated lights skylights, altering work shifts reduce power use peak periods, running computers batteries peak hours, according California Chamber Commerce. ˜˜In areas, Californians adopting spirit public cooperation theatrical flair brought recent drought, installed low-flow toilets shower heads, put bricks toilet tanks even painted unwatered grass green. Conservation tips current crisis include sealing ice cubes plastic containers frost-free freezers keep trying defrost drying laundry old-fashioned clotheslines--though runs afoul apartment regulations often bears there-goes-the-neighborhood stigma attached sight underwear drying outdoors. ˜˜This California, less-conventional ideas floating around: Installing pressure-sensitive escalators run someone stands them; daytime-only baseball; out-of-state guests. ˜˜One San Francisco Chronicle online reader even offered ultimate sacrifice cause: "I drink espresso rather lattes saves energy steam milk." ˜˜Despite inspired suggestions signs changing attitudes toward conserving power, many Californians finding old habits hard break. example, energy-saving fluorescent light bulbs get prime display space hardware stores, hot tubs. state official announces conservation become way life, Disneyland decides resurrect famed Main Street Electrical Parade summer five-year absence. governor's mansion sets thermostat 78 degrees, state Capitol cold enough sweaters. ˜˜Though progress slow, Jorgensens believe less-is-more message finding increasingly receptive audience. key success much generate electricity, use little-about one-quarter one-fifth average household uses. manage this, insist, without serious inconvenience. ˜˜They swelter summer shiver winter. (OK. confront Chicago weather, either.) stumble around dimly lighted rooms. soothing sound falling water heard pump-equipped fountain back yard. ˜˜"There's automatic [negative] reaction say 'conserve' anybody," Eric says. Though one works better lots sun another works better overcast days, work perfectly well, couple says, cooking chicken, pot roast, bread, apple pie whatever else oven good for. ˜˜The Jorgensens' conservation crusade launched bought gadget called Watts Up? meter tell exactly appliance uses. astonished money spending power need really want use. Step 1 involves making cost-effective changes make difference way people live. Switching incandescent fluorescent light bulbs falls category. ˜˜Step 2 consists making changes daily routines spending money. could mean something big getting energy-efficient refrigerator small regularly unplugging electric toothbrush. ˜˜Step 3 installing solar energy. "conservation creep" set in. started hanging laundry line. turned screen computer downloading files. covered heating vent spare room seldom use. ˜˜They believe measures, including clothesline routine, inconvenient, recognize others might lower tolerance things, advise clients adopt progression energy-use changes, beginning with: ˜˜LIGHT BULBS ˜˜"You can't change person's habits," Eric says, "but change light bulbs." ˜˜The Jorgensens replaced almost light bulbs compact fluorescents. know going say: They're ugly, light good. shop around, Eric says. "Every one market completely different. good. bad. blue. pink. flicker. work they're cold." ˜˜They recommend starting putting bulbs places much care quality light, porch example, trying different brands shapes find one like. prefer bulbs vaguely resemble curlicue shape Dairy Queen cone top. "If they're fixture see bulb, can't tell" they're conventional lights, Nicole says. ˜˜THERMOSTAT ˜˜The Jorgensens installed cheap ($20 $40) programmable thermostat heater, winter program cool night mind, warmer get up, cool they're gone day warm get home. San Jose's moderate climate lets skip air conditioning. ˜˜One man came house said conserving heat setting thermostat degrees winter. "Isn't everybody freezing death?" Eric asked. But, like old using energy worth, case 6 kilowatt hours day. "That's whole house uses," Eric notes. ˜˜If must second refrigerator, suggests getting chest freezer setting thermostat freeze cools. "Chest freezers insulation." ˜˜The Jorgensens refrigerator uses 1,350 watts per day, 20 percent less bought put $5 worth extra back. material used, Reflectix, looks like bubble sandwiched foil. ˜˜"It really ticks $900 refrigerator put $5 worth thing would use 20 less says. ˜˜WATER HEATER ˜˜The Jorgensens fans tankless water heaters even though $500, roughly double one tank. tank heater, Eric notes, "sits always tries hot case use it. kind like leaving car running driveway case ever want go ride." contrast, tankless models gas jets demand, water passes way ˜˜The Energy Commission tankless heaters, necessarily much energy money, cautions, large family . . . need laundry wash time others shower, tankless probably meet needs." ˜˜The Jorgensens children, tankless system tested demands large family, Nicole says experience suggests would make difference. ˜˜"You worry five loads laundry running hot water shower," says, supply hot water limited water heater's tank. ˜˜The Jorgensens estimate old water heater cost $500 year run, new tankless one $200. ˜˜PHANTOMS, VAMPIRES WALL WARTS ˜˜Some appliances said "leak" energy; is, use electricity even they're switched off. include devices remote soft-touch keypad appliances off-on switches. study two years ago, Berkeley Lab scientists concluded consumers would save $1 billion year manufacturers applied proven technologies reduce "leaking" component electricity use. ˜˜Devices leak, derisively called "vampires," drive Jorgensens crazy. ˜˜DustBusters? Eric says. ˜˜Then calls "wall boxes part cord small appliances keep warmed small trickle electricity even nominally "off." ˜˜To deal offenses, Jorgensens relentless shoppers. suspicious gaze salespeople one store, couple tore boxes every model answering machine look cord boxes, amount power use stamped them. found answering machine used least "phantom electricity," abandoned instant later discovered combination fax answering machine used even less power. ˜˜They plug VCR television outlet connected off-on switch, put electrical devices power strips shut entirely. ˜˜They also follow manufacturers' instructions electricity vampires. electric toothbrushes, leave plugged in, recommended. found plug day every two weeks, brushes work fine. know brushes need recharged, every two weeks, motor slows down. ˜˜"A lot people can't handle that," Nicole concedes, referring prospect regularly plug unplug devices. "That's much inconvenience. slight change habit, horribly painful, adds up." ˜˜They use battery-run clocks consider electrical ones wasteful. make exception bedroom, yet found battery-powered clock glows dark. ˜˜SOLAR POWER ˜˜The Jorgensens small solar panel cost $100 powers back-yard fountain. Another solar panel powers electric lawnmower. Another generates electricity shed back yard. Yet another one runs attic fan. ˜˜Unlike traditional attic fans people generally house gets hot, one begins turning slowly morning light first hits panel, gradually turns sun gets brighter day gets hotter. slows light diminishes. result, heat never builds attic, Eric says. ˜˜The Jorgensens also generating electricity two large solar panels back roof house, two small windmills. paid $13,008 system received state rebate $5,275, would higher California recently upped rebate encourage conservation. ˜˜They expect investment pay 10 years. (The bathroom features composting toilet, published cookbook features tofu pot pie.) ˜˜Each year, three university students live demonstrate house's energy-saving measures visitors. bungalow one-twentieth power consumed average U.S. household. ˜˜Heat comes wood-burning stove warm air greenhouse, attached south side dwelling. BODY: ˜˜Whenever Los Angeles Lakers play Sacramento, state Assemblyman Rod Wright calls around lobbyists try get tickets. Often, Southern California Edison obliges. ˜˜And utility's generosity goes beyond basketball tickets. Since Wright's election 1996, Edison donated vans impoverished South Central Los Angeles district, given tens thousands campaign contributions underwritten trips Europe South Africa. ˜˜Other campaign fund operated speaker state Assembly, Wright received money Edison 2000 member chamber, state campaign finance records show. ˜˜With California locked power crisis resulted rolling blackouts, Edison courted many lawmakers tries avoid bankruptcy. written favorable company Wright, Democratic chairman Energy Costs Availability Committee. ˜˜"Edison getting lot bang buck" Wright, said Doug Heller, consumer advocate Foundation Taxpayers Consumers Rights. "His single largest contributor one corporation recent legislation would directly bail out." ˜˜There suggestion contributions illegal; duly reported Wright Edison. Jim Knox, director government watchdog group California Common Cause, said close ties cause people worry energy crisis resolved basis campaign contributions. ˜˜Wright makes apologies, saying take money anyone give legally. refused say whether still takes energy contributions, many elected officials declined hot handle since energy crisis started. ˜˜Brian Bennett, Edison vice president external affairs, said standard committee chairman Wright get larger contributions utility. ˜˜Wright "a bright, capable member Legislature interested promoting sound public policy," Bennett said. ˜˜So far, state's second-largest investor-owned utility avoided bankruptcy, Pacific Gas Electric, California's largest, not. ˜˜Wright received overseas trips expense power industry-supported California Foundation Environment Economy. foundation spent total $20,000 taking Wright Europe 1999 South Africa last year. ˜˜During South Africa trip, included Edison lobbyist, Wright spent $7,000 campaign treasury two jewelers. campaign reported expenditures "campaign paraphernalia." ˜˜An Associated Press analysis shows Edison also gave Wright's campaign $22,000 last year $5,000 political action committee supports. ˜˜All told, Edison gave $989,000 California candidates related campaigns 2000 election, state campaign finance records show. ˜˜Although Edison officials say longer give campaign contributions, records show utility spent $318,000 lobbyists first three months year. ˜˜The Democratic speaker Assembly, Bob Hertzberg, stopped taking electricity-related contributions start year returned $34,500 received late 2000. ˜˜Edison gave Gov. Gray Davis $15,000 2000, records show, Assemblyman Fred Keeley, Democrats' leading expert energy policy, received $5,000. year, Keeley said stopped taking energy money. ˜˜"Everyone establish policies, appropriate raising funds folks economic stake crisis that's beleaguering state," Keeley said. ˜˜Wright's contribution debate Edison's came month bill called "straight bailout." Lawmakers analysts considered generous Edison four deals Legislature considering. ˜˜Wright said worked "fairly closely" Edison bill, also consulted consumer groups. ˜˜Now stalled committee, Wright's bill would allowed Edison sell bonds backed customers' rates cover debts, estimated $3.9 billion. Edison customers would repay bonds 10 15 years. ˜˜By contrast, Hertzberg-Keeley bill would allowed Edison sell bonds cover $2.5 billion debts would required utility sell transmission lines state give development rights land near hydroelectric plants. However, version bill circulating Legislature, sale transmission lines dropped. ˜˜If members Senate Assembly meet conference committee settle Edison matter, Wright probably involved. ˜˜On Net: ˜˜Southern California Edison: www.sce.com LOAD-DATE: July 29, 2001 *********** Attached find draft Response Group Motion Relief Stay filed Debtor. initial caveat, prepared scrivener Group. Lorna CEC Blames Overtaxed In-State Gas System Prices Confirming state's energy crisis made abundantly clear ago, California Energy Commission (CEC) staff last week released final draft report state's natural gas infrastructure, concluding constrained caused higher-than-average wholesale gas prices, particularly southern half state. report totally rule market manipulation culprit. concludes combination infrastructure shortcomings possible market manipulation higher natural gas prices California. "Market participants may manipulated prices even higher justified existing infrastructure bottlenecks, inability gas customers rely competition gas suppliers contributed higher prices California," report stated. Among half dozen recommended steps state take help bolster initiatives way utilities merchant energy suppliers, said CEC report, go five-member commission approval Aug. 22. stressed encouraging development "independent" gas storage facilities, taking steps fully "optimize" storage, including increase large end-users. backdrop study's conclusions, CEC report noted upgrades in-state infrastructure interstate pipeline capacity needed meet "growing demand California throughout West." current proposed interstate pipeline expansions come scheduled, CEC report said state actions would necessary, although spell might be. future, report said CEC track storage levels natural gas prices "key extensive problems might given time state's natural gas infrastructure. steps recommended action are: 1) encouraging in-state natural gas production (the state legislature already proposed new law provide incentives); 2) setting new "design criteria reliability standards" state's gas system reflect CEC calls "the changing nature natural gas demand, especially electric generators;" 3) integrated planning state's pipeline storage facilities; 4) developing "natural gas curtailment scheme" emphasizing efficiency optimizing gas use times shortages. 111-page report, "Natural Gas Infrastructure Issues," prepared CEC Electricity Natural Gas Committee final adoption five-member politically appointed commission, assessed state gas industry perspective supply, pipeline capacity (both inter- intrastate) storage, added elements recent historically severe drought Pacific Northwest in-state pipeline constraints California-Arizona border. part proposed implementation, report recommends CEC work closely California Public Utilities develop new curtailment policy "fair time promotes efficient use natural gas" shortage periods. also proposes CEC fall conduct workshop determine ways non-core, large energy-intensive customers better optimize use natural gas storage. -----Original Message----- From: Hyatt, Kevin Sent: Tuesday, August 14, 2001 7:52 To: Brennan, Lorna Subject: RE: Draft Copy CEC's Final Report California Infrastructure Reader's condensed version please!!!!!! -----Original Message----- From: Brennan, Lorna Sent: Monday, August 13, 2001 10:54 To: Chavez, Gabriel; Jeffery Fawcett 04/18/2000 11:37 To: Steven Harris/ET&S/Enron@ENRON, Kevin Hyatt/ET&S/Enron@Enron, Susan Scott/ET&S/Enron@ENRON, Lorraine Lindberg/ET&S/Enron@ENRON, TK Lohman/ET&S/Enron@ENRON, Christine Stokes/ET&S/Enron@ENRON cc: Ronald Matthews/ET&S/Enron@ENRON, Terry Galassini/ET&S/Enron@ENRON Subject: Amerimex Bloomfield Project Attached see note sent Rick Moore. Rick works company called Amerimex. Rick worked together gas supply EPNG ("the early years"). Amerimex developer "trigeneration" projects. addition subject project Bloomfield, another one considered Santa Theresa, N.M. recall, introduced trigeneration discussing electric generation plant site hydroponic tomato greenhouse near Gallup. Trigeneration environmentally friendly technology utilizes "byproducts" electric generation. "Cogeneration" refers process waste heat/steam generated combustion gas turbines sold commercially (usually manufacturing facilities) plant purposes. "Trigeneration," hand, refers process waste heat/steam utilized, also dioxide. Therefore, trigeneration perfect fit greenhouse requires heat carbon dioxide plants. Amerimex proposed hydroponic lettuce greenhouse Bloomfield, N.M. area. facility, constructed turnkey United Technologies, would nominal rating 70 MW, resulting gas burn 15 plant would require gas deliveries approx. 500 psig. outtake power would sold locally grid using TriStates 69kv transmission line proximate site. Given "politically correct" nature facilities, City Farmington agreed fund construction $70MM bond. see, we're earliest stages conversation. TOKYO (Nikkei)--Asserting cuts prices help Japanese companies save much Y4 trillion, major U.S. energy firm Enron Corp. (ENE) Tuesday urged Japanese power revamp electricity market separating operations power generation, transmission distribution, Nihon Keizai Shimbun reported. Enron's 10-point proposal also calls construction power plants full-scale deregulation retail electricity, including sales measures carried electricity prices fall match levels industrialized nations, Japan's industrial sector could trim costs Y4 trillion, Enron said. seminar power industry deregulation hosted Enron, company asserted Japan's deregulation areas wholesale electricity auctions 1996 bulk retail sales last year brought significant benefits end-users. New suppliers entering market account combined 0.4% entire electricity sector, Enron said, criticizing fact power plant facilities mainly concentrated among electric power companies. Regarding prices, official representing operators power generation facilities asserted "industrial-use electricity prices Japan stuck high level around Y13 per kilowatt, compared Y5 U.S., Y3 Canada, Y9 Germany Y4-Y8 Southeast Asia." fact, department store operator Takashimaya Co. (8233 J.TKA), last November switched new market entrants part electricity supply, able cut costs Y450 million first year, company official. Enron hopes competition urging Japanese electric utilities spin different operations, analysts say. number power generation facility operators increases, help bolster Japan's electricity trading market, area Enron business interest. Splitting electricity operations generation, transmission expected open electric utility network new entrants. boost transparency fees electric power companies charge transmitting power behalf operators power generation facilities, Enron says. Citing power shortage California, however, Japan's electricity sector strongly opposed spin-offs, stating generation distribution must part single continuum ensure stable supply. Washington, May 15 (Bloomberg) -- Enron Corp. sell Portland General Electric Co. Oregon state consumers insulated soaring electricity prices, congressman said. ``Purchasing PGE would give Oregon ratepayers control keeping Oregon, accountable solely Oregonians,'' U.S. Representative Peter DeFazio, Democrat Springfield, Oregon, said letter Governor John Kitzhaber. governor considering DeFazio's proposal, said Kitzhaber spokesman Kevin Smith. Last month, Houston-based Enron, biggest energy trader, agreed cancel $3.1 billion sale Portland General, utility 700,000 Oregon customers, Sierra Pacific Resources Reno, Nevada. Enron Sierra Pacific blamed laws spawned high power prices electricity shortages West sale's collapse. ``We pleased keep General asset portfolio solid earnings performer,'' Enron spokeswoman Karen Denne said. ``If approached buyer recognizes value, we'd consider selling it.'' declined comment potential bid Oregon. state act swiftly, DeFazio said, citing press reports U.K.'s Scottish Power Plc, owner PacifiCorp, largest utility U.S Northwest, may bid Portland General. Scottish Power, based Glasgow, Scotland, would 70 percent Oregon electricity customers added Portland General, raising ``serious regulatory concerns market power,'' said. ISO multiply average closing price natural gas last three days NYMEX Henry Hub futures contracts fixed measure generation efficiency various load example, ISO's forecasted load 25,001-30,000, fixed efficiency rate multiplied natural gas price - say - yield rounded price cap Market sources, asked said although ISO filed proposal FERC Oct. 20 requiring utilities boost forward market purchases, forward market reacting negatively Friday price caps. ISO appeared encouraging forward contracts FERC filing latest vote face, traders said. "Traders telling us pulling away forward positions know what's going on," said California Power Exchange spokesman Jesus Arredondo. "On Monday Thursday traded 850 contracts yesterday traded 175. Today's there's nothing. There's one offer $59 per megawatt hour five years one touching it." CalPX, operates state's day-ahead block forward market, plans file formal response ISO proposal FERC. Market sources said CalPX support proposal. Market watchers also said California ever needs buy power market, prices higher cap. summer, ISO spent record $101 million last-minute out-of-state power purchases last summer. "Those inflated out-of-market purchases drove market's high prices summer," said one source close issue. California wholesale electricity prices hit unprecedented levels last summer, customers San Diego's fully deregulated market saw bills triple result. ISO board member Mike Florio, wrote price cap proposal, stressed temporary measure would terminated soon broader market reforms place. "This three-to-four month proposal something going deal going peak period," Florio said. Generators suggested capping market might disincentive looking build new generation state, ISO proposal untimely given FERC's Nov. 1 release California's electricity market problems. "The ISO said (Oct. 20) filing FERC needs venue wholesale market deals agree that," said Duke Energy (DUK) spokesman Tom Williams. Several ISO members proposal also cited FERC's Nov. 1 report presenting possible conflict. "What FERC comes order contrary (to caps) Nov. 1?" said ISO President Terry Winter, voted proposal. Many board members expect vote price caps Thursday's meeting, since vote broader market redesign proposals postponed November. "This wrong time vote comprehensive market redesign today," said board member Barbara Barkovich. Consumer group Utility Reform Network supported proposal, saying action needed control market immediately. Proposal sponsor Florio member TURN. "The ISO responsibility deal without waiting FERC. FERC needs signal ISO serious," said TURN president Nettie Hoge. Hoge also said wary arguments building generation stifled due caps, caps "are well within reasonable level." "It's clear market functioning," Hoge said. Privatizations restructuring activity continue apace. Governments faced burgeoning power demands, lacking funds meet them, nearly universally opening generation markets foreign investors, even privatization agenda. more, state-owned utilities unbundling. Competition introduced national markets wholesale retail levels. international players scaled back international investments shifted substantial portions portfolio less risky markets, U.S. Europe. Competition Europe spurred EU Directive. Asian economies recover, governments starting move forward unbundling / restructuring plans. year currency devaluations caused number early investors exit Latin America, healthier economy allowed privatizations restart, slower pace. mailing summarizes recent Europe, Asia-Pacific, Latin America, Middle East / Africa. Maps summarize status restructuring Europe, Asia, Latin America, Africa Middle East attached Exhibits 1-4. slippery slope Exhibit 5. Timelines showing opening markets various countries, region, Exhibits 6-8. (See attached file: Intlmail 3 exhibits.ppt) February '99 marked opening market choice large EU customers use 40 GWh year. accounts fourth demand. "E-Day", neither France Italy passed proposed enabling legislation. EU intended transmission operator independent, EDF intends retain control grid, ENEL. phased deregulation gas industry began unfold similar fashion beginning August 2000. Mergers, alliances, consolidation dominant theme companies jockey position new European power tremendous opportunity international players cross borders: suppliers new generation, purchasers assets spun liberalization decrees (Italy) market concentration rulings mergers (Germany, Spain). Several companies opened trading offices Europe, ( Enron, Reliant, Southern, TXU). HoustonStreet.com launched European online wholesale energy-trading platform. “ Austria: Austria's liberalizing market facing problems within without. EU dissatisfied lack G-T-D unbundling, although accounts formally separated 1999. ISO. Internally, intense discussion accelerated market opening (customers 20 GWh choice). Regional utilities angry Verbund's proposal open 100% market 2001. Verbund, 51% SOU, largest generator owns grid. However, retail customers hence strongly exposed already deregulated wholesale customers. (C.B. White, Judith Lezaun) “ Denmark: 1999 liberalization law exceeds EU directive's goals establishes full retail access 2003. Choice phased large industrials using 100 GWh 1997; threshold dropped April '00 10 GWh; next threshold drops 1GWh end 2000. new law includes unbundling distribution activity regulated TPA. Denmark recently experienced consolidation wave generation leaves sector 2 large incumbents. trend moving downstream distribution supply. Western Denmark already part Nordic power exchange NordPool East Denmark due join end 2000. Energy policy aims twenty percent electricity sales would come renewables end 2003, current 10%. (Cecilia Bergman) “ Finland: Finland fully open choice since September 1998, metering requirement dropped. Prices dropped, 2-3% households switched supplier. Finland forms part Nordic power NordPool. regulator monitors distribution tariffs rTPA regime place. November '98, Finnish government launched IPO 20% Fortum, holding company merger utility Imatran Voima Oy oil gas company Neste Oy. Finnish government expects lower ownership further. largest new entrant market Swedish Vattenfall, acquisitions distributors generation capacity. M&A distribution supply sector expected. (Cecilia Bergman) “ France: irony France's push liberalization assumed six-month EU presidency. France passed electricity law last February, year required EU directive, 30-odd implementation decrees stalled National Assembly. However, EDF, still controls 95% French generation, realized Brussels would hinder foreign ambitions domestic market remained closed. recently convinced French authorities open 34% market end 2000 instead 2003, lowering eligibility threshold 9 GWh/year (from 16 GWh). EDF also aware monopoly prevents easily entering energy services market -- leading EDF promote "relatively rapid" total opening French market. (Corinne Aigroz, White) “ Germany: Electricity Law officially effective April '98, real competition still impeded complicated TPA grid access conditions, especially retail market. group new entrants organized call governmental regulator. recent studies shown cost electricity low bills indicate "massive cross-subsidization network operations marketing." Recent charges made obstacles competition mulitiplicity fees, including customer switching charges supplier entrants registration levies. last 12 months, M&A among big national international utilities redrawn German utility landscape: EDF bought share EnBW, Veba / Viag merged form EON RWE/VEW merged RWE. Furthermore, RWE EON must sell stakes VEAG due antitrust authority. Currently, several utilities battling control East German VEAG, whose transmission connections make portal Eastern Europe. (Judith Lezaun, White) “ Greece: According FT, Greece "hired consultant" (us) produce 5-year plan state utility PPC. PPC preparing IPO 15-20% company, theoretically set 2001, likely later. Greece given 2001 EU conform Directive. IEA report suggested two major swift changes energy sector structure. First, government create clearer separation state-owned PPC, including separate regulatory agency. Second, government consider splitting PPC competing generators maximize competition, well market access conditions IPPs cogenerators. country's largest employer, PPC likely effect changes quickly. (White, Thomas Read) “ Ireland: Supply competition February '00 customers 4 GWh (28% market). Opening scheduled increase 32% 2003, liberalisation 2006. date mid-market full retail opening set. Incumbent ESB plans split transmission business, remain state-owned. Competition generation introduced 2002 auctioning ESB capacity, intended create least two new players. Independent power production allowed two years now. (Ben Joyce) “ Italy: Italy approved market deregulation decree March '99; measures, goes beyond EU Directive. ENEL dominated 80% generation; 2003, entity control 50%, 30% 2005. requires ENEL sell 15GW 22GW 57GW 2003. separated G-T-D separate legal entities 34.5% privatized. second tranche take place 2001. pool mechanism operating 2001. Consortia industrials using 30GWh/year contract directly IPPs; 2002, threshold year. potential free market currently amounts 80 TWh year, 30% total demand. increase 40% 2002. ENEL, de facto monopoly T&D, retain ownership national grid assets; separate state-run ISO, GRTN, run transmission dispatching. pool mechanism, operated GRTN subsidiary, operating 2001; meantime, uses bilateral contracts. (Valentina Grifo, White) “ Netherlands: June '00 three four large generation companies sold energy groups. Competition large industrial users began August '98. Large industrials (33% market) currently choose supplier. 2002, 58% market competitive, 2004, full customer choice. Amsterdam Power Exchange, along Scandinavian lines, launched May '99. APX allows players trade power Internet hourly basis day. April '00, added day-ahead prices border points although yet much used; successful, Belgium would follow. October '00, government agreed buy entire high voltage network, TenneT, four generation companies $99.1 million. goal improve supply market increase real competition. (White, Karel Tutein Nolthenius) “ Norway: Norway opened retail access one fell swoop 1991. "Real" retail access got started 1995 meter requirement abolished; switching got started 1997 switching fee canceled. current accumulated switching rate lies 14%. Distribution tariffs regulated transparent according rTPA. Norway forms part NordPool. (Cecilia Bergman) Portugal: Portugal brought new regulations force January '99. include price-cap system tariffs creation two coexisting supply systems: public independent. locked supplying national grid (REN), regulated EdP-owned monopoly. Producers system currently supply eligible customers consume 9GWh/year single site. country's four discos may purchase 8% consumption outside public system. regulator, ERSE, either extend eligible customers raise allowed percent order reach percents required government sold another stake 20% state-owned Electricidade de Portugal October '00, following two successful offerings '97 '98. offering raised $1.34 billion. state retains 32.6% "golden share" rights. Banks want detailed papers treatment retail, equity project finance portfolios. also asking information way operational risk - unexpected losses - treated, details aspects securitisation, counterparty risk disclosure. letter points number important areas Basle committee's second consultation document either come new proposals indicated final proposals come. KfW seeks Basle II changes IFR - May 19, 2001 Kreditanstalt fuer Wiederaufbau (KfW), Germany's largest promotional bank, intends bring four items discussion surrounding revised Basle Capital Accord (Basle II). Hans Reich, agency's managing board chairman, said modifications necessary supply credit small medium-sized enterprises future. particular, KfW wants customary collateral categories recognised equally fully risk rating approaches. also wants Basle II small loans, small businesses, combined so-called retail portfolios ratings approaches. Referring advanced IRB approach Basle II paper's requirement higher equity held loans long maturity, KfW considers discrimination customary long-term lending relations long established German banking system. KfW also considers Basle II proposals subject securitisation unclear. argues care needs taken ensure new requirements run counter SME loans securitisation, reduce risk banks. Reich expressed satisfaction firm's "intensive constructive" talks German finance ministry points. "We pleased politicians dealing intensively topic SME finance necessary changes required Basle II," said. Creditors Must Better Measure Fund Exposures - BIS Dow Jones - May 21, Tyler Lifton NEW YORK -(Dow Jones)- good progress made towards strengthening counterparty credit risk management regulatory oversight highly leveraged institutions (HLI), credit providers need make improvements measurement credit exposures, global banking watchdog said Friday. 'Friction developed swaps securities contracts regard netting across them," says Dan Cunningham, partner Allen & Overy New York ISDA's legal counsel. ISDA BMA worked issue since 1995. Nearly provisions requested included legislation. House Representatives Senate versions bill currently reconciled, little doubt netting provisions included bill eventually President Bush signature. U Securities Trade Groups Argue Firm's Liability Sophisticated Investors Certain Trades BNA - May 22, 2001 Bond Market Association, Futures Industry Association, Foreign Exchange Committee Federal Bank New York told U.S. Court Appeals Second Circuit May 21 sophisticated investors permitted sue financial institutions carrying "nondiscretionary" transactions credit markets, BMA said day (de Kwiatkowski v. Bear Stearns & Co., 2d Cir., No. 01-7112, 5/21/01). amicus curiae brief, groups allowing suits would lead '"heads win, tails sue' liability framework would integrity efficiency financial markets,'" BMA said news release. "This critically important case fixed-income industry," BMA General Counsel Paul Saltzman said release. "If appeals court upholds legal reasoning underlying district court's decision, counterparties want juries second guess every good faith action financial institutions seek reimbursement every losing trade," predicted. organizations sought overturn decision rendered late last year U.S. District Court Southern District New York. Henryk deKwiatkowski, wealthy Canadian investor, engaged series currency futures contracts currency forward contracts purchased Chicago Mercantile Exchange over-the-counter markets. contracts carried Bear Stearns & Co. futures commission merchant (FCM) principal, BMA recounted. Responsibility Customer district court decided "special circumstances" supported jury verdict Kwiatkowski Bear Stearns. However, brief argued responsibility trading decisions accounts rests customer precluded liability instance Bear Stearns. '"Customers suffer market losses able effect 'end run' around carefully defined limitations duties broker alleging violations general duty care," groups wrote. three groups contended wide range factors affect market price futures contract, imposition '"any continuing duty furnish price information information facts likely affect market price would burdensome unreasonable."' case, said, deKwiatkowski's financial losses brought market factors. "'De Kwiatkowski speculated dollar would appreciate--and would profited handsomely had--but Mexican debt crisis intervened, dollar fell, incurred losses,'" brief said. 'special circumstances' case--yet precisely sort circumstances participants face markets day day out,'" said. Reliance Contracts need legal certainty, credit markets must rely heavily contracts permit market intermediaries customers counterparties identify precise nature products, services, functions purchased, brief observed. "'Market participants need able expect participants held contractual allocations risk markets perform effectively efficiently, especially futures OTC derivatives markets, risk loss inheres every trade.'" three organizations urged. absence certainty introduces risk, hurt market efficiency, liquidity, costs. disregarding precedents New York law, court's opinion runs counter legal certainty markets require, brief said. "The district court effect created broad new 'malpractice' cause action brokers regarding 'handling' accounts--which plainly odds New York law," brief maintained. narrow scope broker's duty nondiscretionary account New York law applies fully futures broker, groups wrote. long-standing legal precedent, duty owed futures broker nondiscretionary account "exceedingly narrow one," relating properly carrying transactions ordered customer, brief noted. Dealers similarly narrow responsibilities, argued. Market intermediaries may agree perform additional services, discretionary trading investment advisory services, absence explicit agreement, "'the risk venture upon customer, profits succeeds loses fails,'" brief summed up. limits ingenuity Financial Times - May 16, 2001 pace financial innovation slowing? pose question, global financial markets appear trapped perpetual maelstrom, may seem quixotic. Airlines food beverage firms targeted IFR - May 19, 2001 true commodity, weather derivatives still long way go. power weather derivative officials FOW's third annual Derivatives Expo last week encouraged new breed end-users expect see using weather derivatives, particularly airlines, food beverage firms, agricultural/fertiliser firms, construction firms. Airlines, especially concentrated particular hub, could use weather derivatives actively since inclement weather prompt many delays used to, notes Claudio Ribeiro, head new products development, weather risk management group, Enron. Food beverage firms also viewed prime targets could use weather derivatives manage cashflows better. companies need hedges since weather increase decrease firm's sales dramatically. Food beverage firms typically benefit warm weather, occasion, food chain, example, enjoy increased sales cold spells weather extreme enough keep customers indoors. firms beginning ask questions "If there's going really hot summer, affect bottom-line? systematic weather risk going cost summer?" adds Cameron Rookley, financial economist Caminus. Use weather derivatives agricultural sector companies also logical step, according people industry, especially hedge guaranteed sale. Though underlying market exists, power weather derivatives providers pinned hopes growth market supply demand derivatives. "No one buy sunny day. buy cost risk associated sunny day," says Ribeiro. way entering swaps options limits. transactions capped reduce aggregate exposure US$100m. structures mostly seasonal feature multi-year terms. "Weather to-date sufficiently fungible us build broad market on, yet pretty big market nonetheless," adds Robert Levin, senior vice-president, planning control development, New York Mercantile Exchange. Since September 1997, first weather derivatives trade occurred, market experienced estimated 4,500 weather transactions worth US$6bn. Much weather derivatives use occurring natural gas, propane electricity markets. Markets currently made heating degree days (HDD), cooling degree days (CDD) variations collars, forwards swaps. "Through OTC market, create kind structure," Ribeiro says. One brake faster growth weather derivatives lack historical data. compensate, realistic hourly weather simulation engine needed could replicate thousands multi-regional weather scenarios, said Rookley. model could capture seasonal hourly patterns normal temperatures, extent temperatures deviate normal level, speed temperatures tend return norm. would also handle correlation across weather station pairings. UK building societies' use credit derivatives limited IFR - May 19, 2001 Jean Haggerty UK Treasury's legislation allowing building societies use credit derivatives protect assets borrower default may fail societies credit derivatives market. Initial hopes Treasury's move fortnight ago would prompt societies embrace synthetic securitisations - thus help fuel credit derivative market growth. closer examination, hopes seem fading. "It unlikely big market. building societies remaining. Also, assets suitable synthetic securitisation relatively small," said Chris Carman, vice-president within JP Morgan's structured products group London. Building societies' mortgage assets predominantly owner-occupied residential mortgages, such, 50% capital weighting Bank International Settlement purposes. "This weighting means hold least 4% capital asset. So, synthetic securitisation would take capital weighting 20%. deal would produce limited capital savings," Carman said. also means that, unlike banks large proportion 100% weighted assets, building societies limited incentive seek regulatory capital relief via transaction, said Simon Gleeson, partner solicitors Allen & Overy London. mutual societies, also pressure improve return equity, noted. smaller building societies may candidates synthetic securitisations cheaper require less documentation traditional securitisations, others may concentrations large enough warrant use synthetic securitisations. smaller building societies may viable candidates synthetic securitisations, may able build infrastructure required otherwise actively trade credit derivatives, noted Janet Tavakoli, executive director head structuring engineering credit derivatives WestLB London. Building societies would need securitising asset pool E500m warrant entering transaction cost putting together transactions quite sizeable, industry officials said. Regulatory barriers Building Societies Commission (BSC), industry's regulator, last week sent letters UK building societies, saying building societies deemed sophisticated treasury departments able use credit derivatives products without asking permission ahead execution. 12 societies fall category. building society's ability use credit derivatives hinges fits BSC-created spectrum assigns eligibility based criteria sufficient experience using derivatives adequate systems capture handle credit derivatives business. institution ranked middle five-tier spectrum apply make strong case able use credit derivatives. Building societies ranked last two categories allowed participate credit derivatives market. Even building societies large mortgage books may reject idea using synthetic securitisations, said Nick Rice, associate director Royal Bank Scotland London. "The top-tier building societies better rated. Therefore, issuing vanilla debt easier synthetic securitisations," said. rapid growth credit derivatives market spurred increase synthetic securitisations. British Bankers Association (BBA) last summer projected credit derivatives market would reach US$1.5trn (notional outstanding) 2002. 1997, synthetic securitisations used method mitigating risks, BBA estimated credit derivatives market roughly US$180bn. Building societies likely use synthetic securitisations new product areas way transfer risk related new product transferring risk higher-weighted assets, industry officials said. Buy-to-let mortgages might prove area ripe synthetic securitisation 100% weighted UK, said JP Morgan's Carman. "Building societies could also look [synthetically] securitise commercial lending," added. this, too, would need hold 8% regulatory capital, said. changes enabling building societies use credit derivatives occurred BSC's regulatory jurisdiction building societies transferred FSA November. "When new Basle Accord comes in, building societies subject FSA's bank rules. forced look credit risk management," said Simon Firth, partner head derivatives practice Linklaters London. new Basle proposal, building societies option using 50% capital weighting residential mortgage assets using internal risk-based approach. Mortgage guarantees According industry officials, building societies' current practice using insurance reduce borrower risk may turn prompts enter credit derivatives market. "Theoretically, credit derivatives could take place mortgage guarantees. could say, 'Instead getting insurance policy someone takes loan, portfolio trade?'," said Firth. Unlike credit derivatives, mortgage guarantees carry insurance premium tax. unclear cost using mortgage guarantees compares credit derivatives, however. ban UK building societies' use credit derivatives dates back 1986 Building Societies Act, subsequent amendments it, preceded development credit derivatives market. societies able use interest rate foreign exchange derivatives. order allowing use credit derivatives comes force July 1. coast blues Risk - May 2001 good quarter big US energy trading firms. MSEB reportedly owes central utilities Rs 5,000 crore. cannot bring charge many types users power consumed, prevent large-scale theft electricity. Few, including wealthy Maharashtra, reform state electricity privatise transmission distribution. Given profile buyers, private generators demand sovereign guarantees help tide default risks. guarantees merely insulate IPPs risk. cannot make SEBs solvent. Yet, India needs power desperately. Maharashtra, India,s richest state, experiences power shortages around 2,000 MW, sixth peak needs. time, hunger power grow. India cannot afford wait painful politics SEB reform work out. government bring legislation allows IPPs sell power directly paying customers.This free IPPs clutches bankrupt monopsony buyers. power trading legislation unexpectedly happy consequences government too.Once IPPs freed onerous obligations sell power single, mostly bankrupt buyers, default risks come substantially. New Delhi state governments scrap guarantees gave IPPs past. combination power trading, private investments generation, transmission distribution, gradual SEB reform create commercial, workable competitive power market India. Anything less recipe disaster. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ ------- State give tax sops DPC buying naphtha IOC, (Sanjay Jog) Thursday Jan 18 2001 Maharshtra government's finance department, striving reduce fiscal deficit Rs 9,484 crore Rs 3,484 crore beginning April year, expressed inability provide sales tax waiver Dabhol Power Company (DPC) procurement 1.2 million tonne naphtha state-run Indian Oil Corporation (IOC). Mantralaya sources told Financial Express Wednesday DPC would pay 4 per cent sales tax. "The government, way back 1995, modified sales tax rate 4 per cent discourage import naphtha Gujarat electrical companies operating Maharashtra. decision taken view encouraging electrical companies procure naphtha reduced rates within state," government sources added. Sources said companies pay nearly 15.3 per cent sales tax naphtha procured Gujarat. However, following representation, government slashed sales tax rate 4 per cent. state finance department's opinion, would presented state cabinet shortly order take final decision, deserves special significance especially state energy department loss-making Maharashtra State Electricity Board (MSEB) wholeheartedly supported DPC's cause recommended sales tax waiver. DPC, asked Union ministry oil procure naphtha within country view excess availability, presentation state government MSEB, made clear would left alternative pass additional burden MSEB would ultimately passed consumers. DPC also told state government paid sales tax procurement naphtha Glencore calender year 2000. Sources state energy department MSEB stressed need waiver expressing inability bear additional burden. suggested state reciprocate offering sales tax exemption DPC IOC, behest Centre, tried match international landing price naphtha recently signed memorandum agreement DPC. Impact Price Caps attached spreadsheet contains table likely maximum monthly prices different gas price levels. think highest markets would clear since assumes hour clears cap. hard say whether actual prices would clear significantly lower cap know whether sellers offer cap cap. assumptions behind analysis detailed bullets below. Take actual historical loads 1999 2000. Calculate implied price cap hour using actual historical load, new price cap methodology, range gas prices. Divide historical hours peak off-peak buckets. Calculate average price month peak hours off-peak hours. example, two years worth data months January September. month approximately 400 hours. January September, took 800 observations month (400 year) calculated simple average individual observations. created peak table off-peak table. table shows calculated implied cap based acutal loads varying gas prices month. value represents month would clear hour cleared cap (based historic loads). given hour could value, calculation estimates likely monthly average cap value! blue shading indicates caps would given current (10/27/2000 NYMEX) forward prices. yellow shading indicates forward power prices excess proposed cap. *********** Attached preliminary "Buyback & Deficiency Deals" worksheet July 2000 activity. *********** ----- Forwarded Sara Shackleton/HOU/ECT 08/29/2000 11:36 ----- Carol St Clair 08/29/2000 08:13 To: Sara Shackleton/HOU/ECT@ECT, Mary Cook/HOU/ECT@ECT cc: Subject: Enron/McGarret C Transaction Carol St. Clair EB 3892 713-853-3989 (Phone) 713-646-3393 (Fax) carol.st.clair@enron.com ----- Forwarded Carol St Clair/HOU/ECT 08/29/00 08:10 ----- "CHRIS KRECEK" <KRECC@andrews-kurth.com> 08/28/00 12:53 PM To: <alan.quaintance@enron.com>, <brenda.l.funk@enron.com>, <Carol.St.Clair@enron.com>, <charles.delacey@enron.com>, <Clement.abrams@enron.com>, <David.roland@enron.com>, <Gina.Karathanos@enron.com>, <Joel.ephross@enron.com>, <tina.livingston@enron.com>, <Trevor.Randolph@enron.com>, <trushar.patel@enron.com>, <mniebruegge@mayerbrown.com>, <tellwood@mayerbrown.com>, <eawilburn@prickett.com>, <Tamullen@prickett.com>, <kenton@rlf.com>, <mark.wolf@us.cibc.com>, <mercedes.arango@us.cibc.com>, <schottla@us.cibc.com>, <aroberts@wilmingtontrust.com> cc: "David Barbour" <BARBD@andrews-kurth.com>, "MURIEL McFARLING" <MCFAM@andrews-kurth.com>, "Michael Thimmig" <THIMM@andrews-kurth.com> Subject: Enron/McGarret C Transaction Attached WordPerfect format following documents marked version previously circulated: Drawdown Request (254322); Put Option Agreement (254334); Warrant Assignment (254351); Amended Restated LLC Agreement McGarret III (254352); Receipt Asset LLC (254362); Independent Auctioneer Letter Agreement (254369); Direction Letter (254376); Sale Auction Agreement (254372); General Opinion A&K (254385). questions comments, please call Muriel McFarling (214) 659-4461. Shipper agrees Gas received Houston Receipt Points hereunder Houston agrees Gas delivered hereunder account Shipper Delivery Points hereunder shall merchantable Gas shall: a. total heating value less nine hundred fifty (950) Thermal Units per cubic foot saturated wator vapor (gross basis); b. commercially free dust, hydrocarbon liquids, water, suspended matter, gums gum forming constituents objectionable substances; c. contain twenty (20) total sulfur, one-fourth (1/4) grain hydrogen sulfide per one hundred (100) standard cubic feet Receipt Points one (1) grain hydrogen sulfide per one hundred (100) standard cubic feet Delivery Points; d. Contain two percent (2%) volume carbon dioxide, two tenths one percent (0.2%) volume oxygen, three percent (3%) volume total inerts; e. temperature one hundred twenty degrees Fahrenheit (120F.) less forty degrees Fahrenheit (40F.); f. contain seven (7) pounds entrained water vapor per million cubic feet; g. hydrocarbon dewpoint 45"F less pipeline operating pressures 200 psig 1100 psig. Shipper shall responsible odorizing part Gas delivered hereunder Shipper's account diverted and/or used Shipper purpose odorization required pursuant regulations Railroad Texas. Gas delivered either party hereunder fail meet quality specifications above, either party shall notify party responsible deficiency shall make diligent effort correct failure. party receiving deficient Gas shall right refuse accept Gas long party unable deliver Gas conforming specifications, either party may accept delivery Gas part thereof period. either party's tender deficient Gas hereunder extend period greater sixty (60) Days, receiving party shall right option end sixty (60) Days, long thereafter party continues tender non-conforming Gas, terminate Agreement twenty-four (24) hours advance written notice party stating effective date termination. However, continued quibble create set data points would inputs testing process. Last week consulting arm "Big Five" accounting firm indicated following method proposed us would acceptable. believe method overcomes problems arise using interest differences ("rolling") quarters. Method: 1)Calculate daily yield curve changes expressed ratios, using historical rates recent, say, two years. (Note: overlap). set around 494 vectors ratios (approximately 247 trading days per year). Example: first yield curves historical set look like this: 19980801 6.5 6.6 6.7 ......... 7.2 19980802 6.3 6.3 6.6 ......... 6.9 19980803 6.6 6.8 6.9 ......... 7.1 change 8/1/98 8/2/98 is: 6.3/6.5 6.3/6.6 6.6/6.7 .......... 6.9/7.1 change 8/2/98 8/3/98 is: 6.6/6.3 6.8/6.3 6.9/6.6 ......... 7.1/6.9 2)Randomly select 62 "ratio" vectors (approx. 62 trading days quarter). 3)Multiply ratio vectors together get single vector (ie, 62 6mo ratios multiplied together, 62 1yr ratios multiplied togeter, etc.). result represents single quarterly yield curve transformation. Apply "today's" yield curve. resulting yield curve represents one simulated quarterly change interest rates 4)Repeat steps 2 3 adequate number yield generated, say 100. 5) Proceed testing process. would interested comments. "Even could force refunds, would take five 10 years court decide generators refund money," commissioner said. "I think state willing spend money addition, commission nowhere near deciding whether Edison International (EIX) unit Southern California Edison PG&E Corp. (PCG) unit Pacific Gas & Electric pass combined $5 billion debt ratepayers, commissioner said. decision likely made mid-2001, commissioner added. PUC President Loretta Lynch Carl Wood support generators refund windfall profits utilities commission's investigation, one two ongoing probes state's troubled wholesale power market, unsuccessful finding evidence would force generators refund billions dollars, according documents obtained Thursday Dow Jones Newswires. week, federal regulators generators manipulate flaws state's market structure said rates "unjust unreasonable." state's Independent Operator Exchange also concluded evidence prove generators manipulated market order drive wholesale power prices. said PUC support utilities' efforts pass $5 billion wholesale power costs ratepayers. commissioner said "if came deciding tomorrow, utilities would left holding bag." PG&E SoCal Edison pay 16 cents kilowatt-hour wholesale power. utilities charge customers far less state-mandated rate freeze. reported earlier Thursday, SoCal President Chief Executive Officer Stephen Frank said utility's inability immediately recover $2 billion debt ratepayers may force company lay employees reduce major capital spending. BridgeStation users find links company data end: PG&amp;E Bankruptcy Affect Calpine's Commitment California Power Market /FROM PR NEWSWIRE SAN FRANCISCO 415-543-7800/ BUSINESS ENERGY EDITORS: PG&amp;E Bankruptcy Affect Calpine's Commitment California Power Market SAN JOSE, Calif., April 9 /PRNewswire/ -- Pacific Gas Electric Company's (PG&amp;E) April 6th 11 filing, Calpine Corporation (NYSE: CPN), San Jose, Calif.-based independent power company, stated confident PG&amp;E, successful reorganization, able pay Calpine's Qualifying Facility (QF) subsidiaries past due power sales, addition electricity deliveries made going-forward basis. CALPINE'S QF SUBSIDIARIES POWER PG&amp;E TERMS LONG-TERM QF CONTRACTS ELEVEN FACILITIES, REPRESENTING NEARLY 600 MEGAWATTS ELECTRICITY CALIFORNIA POWER CUSTOMERS. MARCH 31, 2001, CALPINE RECORDED APPROXIMATELY $267 MILLION ACCOUNTS RECEIVABLE PG&amp;E, PLUS $68 MILLION NOTE RECEIVABLE DUE PAYABLE. COMPANY'S REMAINING CALIFORNIA OPERATIONS, TOTALING APPROXIMATELY 700 MEGAWATTS CAPACITY, PROVIDE ELECTRICITY MUNICIPALITIES CREDITWORTHY THIRD CALPINE'S QF FACILITIES PART 9,000-MEGAWATT QF SUPPLY PROVIDE CALIFORNIA CUSTOMERS LONG-TERM SOURCE ELECTRICITY PRICES SIGNIFICANTLY CURRENT WHOLESALE PRICES. CRITICAL POWER SUPPLY REPRESENTS APPROXIMATELY 33 PERCENT POWER DEMAND. WITHOUT CONTRACTS PLACE SUMMER, CALIFORNIA FACES PROSPECT BLACKOUTS HUNDREDS MILLIONS DOLLARS INCREASED COSTS. QF CONTRACTS CONTINUE, PG&amp;E MUST ASSUME CONTRACTS BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS. ORDER ASSUME CONTRACTS, PG&amp;E REQUIRED CURE OUTSTANDING DEFAULTS, INCLUDING PAYING PAST DUE AMOUNTS. PG&amp;E FAILS ASSUME CONTRACTS, CALPINE'S QF ABLE SELL POWER OPEN MARKET DAMAGES PG&amp;E BREACH CONTRACT BANKRUPTCY CLAIMS RESOLUTION PROCESS. state's leading developer new electric generating facilities, Calpine remains committed providing innovative solutions California's _________________________________________________________ Individual.com #1 provider free, individualized news information business people Internet. JULIE TAMAKI, Times Staff Writer SACRAMENTO--The rolling blackouts swept California Monday sparked part crucial group small energy producers cut supplies state's utilities paid. California's power supply dropped Monday alternative producers reduced output went offline, cutting usual deliveries utilities half. lost electricity--more seven times cuts companies making weeks ago--could served 3 million homes.
